<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_map:
```c
int metal_map(int fd, off_t offset, size_t size, int expand, int flags,
	      void **result)
{
	int prot = PROT_READ | PROT_WRITE, error;
	void *mem;

	flags |= MAP_SHARED;

	if (fd < 0) {
		fd = -1;
		flags = MAP_PRIVATE | MAP_ANONYMOUS;
	} else if (expand) {
		off_t reqsize = offset + size;
		struct stat stat;

		error = flock(fd, LOCK_EX) < 0 ? -errno : 0;
		if (!error)
			error = fstat(fd, &stat);
		if (!error && stat.st_size < reqsize)
			error = ftruncate(fd, reqsize);
		if (!error)
			flock(fd, LOCK_UN);
		if (error)
			return -errno;
	}

	mem = mmap(NULL, size, prot, flags, fd, offset);
	if (mem == MAP_FAILED)
		return -errno;
	*result = mem;
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>

explanation: No compiler language extensions are used in the provided code fragment. The function uses standard C syntax and POSIX API calls/macros (mmap, PROT_*, MAP_*, MAP_FAILED, flock, fstat, ftruncate, errno, off_t, size_t, struct stat), which are OS/library features rather than compiler language extensions. There are no occurrences of known compiler-specific language extensions such as __attribute__ or __declspec, typeof, statement expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, inline assembler (asm), labels-as-values (&label), GCC statement-expression or sizeof on VLA in an extension-only way, zero-length arrays, or other constructs explicitly documented as compiler extensions. The mixed declaration-and-code inside the block (off_t reqsize = ...; struct stat stat;) is standard C (C99 and later) rather than a compiler extension. Therefore there are no fragments to flag for MISRA C:2023 Rule 1.2 (use of language extensions).
